summary: RAG evaluation refers to the systematic assessment of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models that combine retrieval mechanisms with generative language modeling to improve performance on tasks such as question answering and information retrieval. This evaluation employs diverse metrics including exact match, functional correctness, and text similarity, focusing on benchmarking models to measure quality, comparative ranking, and guiding iterative development. Embedded within AI and LLM engineering best practices, RAG evaluation forms a critical part of the AI model lifecycle, from training pipelines to deployment, within a data-centric architecture that supports flexibility and continuous improvement.
why_it_matters: RAG evaluation is vital for ensuring the effectiveness and reliability of hybrid retrieval-generative systems that enhance language model capabilities. It addresses the complexities inherent in both retrieval and generation, enabling precise measurement of model quality and comparison across multiple approaches. This informs development choices, maintains high standards for AI applications, supports ongoing model refinement, and ultimately leads to more accurate, contextually relevant, and robust AI-powered systems in real-world use cases.

In this accessible guide, author Chip Huyen discusses AI engineering: the process of building applications 
with readily available foundation models. AI application developers will discover how to navigate 
the AI landscape, including models, datasets, evaluation benchmarks, and the seemingly infinite number 
of application patterns. The book also introduces a practical framework for developing an AI application 
and efficiently deploying it.

Note that we never said not to use OpenAI’s GPT API, just that the LLM framework we will pres-
ent is LLM-agnostic. Thus, if it can be manipulated programmatically and exposes a fine-tuning 
interface, it can be integrated into the LLM Twin system we will learn to build. The key to most 
successful ML products is to be data-centric and make your architecture model-agnostic. Thus, 
you can quickly experiment with multiple models on your specific data.
